author: Higginson, H. Talbot.
snippet: throughout the world for its linen and handkerchiefs; a little further onin Donegall Place is Lindsay's Ulster Arcade, and further on, on thesame side, is the Imperial Hotel, one of the finest hotels in the city;on the opposite side is the Royal Hotel, and Rodman's great art shopand picture gallery; near this is the Queen's Arcade, a large coveredpromenade, with fine shops on either side; and in Castle Place is theBank Buildings, once the Northern Bank, a grand emporium for allsorts of goods; facing which is Gibson's famous jewellery shop, andnext to it is Magill's art shop and picture gallery; facing DonegallPlace is the Ulster Club, where once stood Sloan's famous cabinetwarehouse, Page's hair-cutting establishment, and Ogston's pastry shop. At the corner of Royal Avenue, which was at one time a filthy street ofsmall butcher and other shops, but now one of the finest thoroughfaresin the city, is the Reform Club; and on the opposite side is the RoyalAvenue Hotel, a splendid establishment.

title: Notes by the Way; or, what I saw in my rambles
author: Higginson, H. Talbot.
snippet: At the top ofFrederick Street is North Queen Street, where the barracks for footand cavalry soldiers are situated. High Street is a broad fine street,running from the quays up to Castle Place, and one of the busiestthoroughfares in the city, having splendid shops on each side ; and offit, facing Corn Market, is Lombard Street, where the famous LombardTemperance Cafe' is situated. This street was once a wretched lane,filled with low oyster saloons and bad houses, but now a fine street.

title: Notes by the Way; or, what I saw in my rambles
author: Higginson, H. Talbot.
snippet: Academical Institution, a famous school where I got my first lessons inpainting in water colours from Mr. Molloy; with other Academies andSchools; Poorhouse, Jail (connected with the Courthouse by a coveredway), Municipal and Commercial Buildings, Banks, Barracks, Deaf andDumb Institution, Museum, Public Library, Theatre, General PostOffice, Lunatic Asylum, Hospitals, and many churches and chapels ofan imposing appearance. The finest thoroughfare in Belfast is from the Linen Hall, throughDonegall Place, Castle Place, Royal Avenue, York Street, to theNorthern Counties Railway—a distance of about one mile. The LinenHall is a square of linen warehouses, enclosing a courtyard, and enclosedby trees and iron railings, in Donegall Square, on each side of whichare fine warehouses.
